meta.notes: 100 MCQs with difficulty 20% easy, 30% moderate, 50% hard; correct options balanced across A–D; explanations include why distractors are wrong.

questions.stem: First-line acute therapy for migraine with moderate to severe attacks in a patient without vascular disease is:
questions.explanation: Triptans are first-line for moderate–severe migraine in low vascular risk. Acetaminophen alone is often insufficient. Ergots are second-line with more AEs. Opioids are not first-line due to dependence and poorer efficacy.

questions.stem: Which drug inhibits GABA transaminase, increasing CNS GABA levels?
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin irreversibly inhibits GABA-T. Tiagabine inhibits GABA reuptake (GAT-1). Topiramate enhances GABA-A and blocks AMPA/Na+. Levetiracetam binds SV2A.

questions.stem: Which Parkinson medication provides symptomatic benefit by COMT inhibition?
questions.explanation: Entacapone inhibits COMT, prolonging levodopa effect. Selegiline inhibits MAO-B. Amantadine increases dopamine release/blocks NMDA. Benztropine is anticholinergic for tremor.

questions.stem: Which antiepileptic has highest teratogenic risk (e.g., neural tube defects)?
questions.explanation: Valproate has the highest teratogenicity. Lamotrigine and levetiracetam are relatively safer. Carbamazepine carries intermediate risk.

questions.stem: Which drug is a dopamine D2 receptor blocker used to treat acute agitation with risk of QT prolongation and dystonia?
questions.explanation: Haloperidol is a high-potency typical antipsychotic with EPS and QT risk. Quetiapine is lower D2 potency. Clozapine causes agranulocytosis. Pimavanserin is 5-HT2A inverse agonist for PDP.

questions.stem: Primary mechanism of action of baclofen:
questions.explanation: Baclofen is a GABA-B agonist used for spasticity. Benzodiazepines are GABA-A modulators. Tizanidine is alpha-2 agonist. Sodium channel blockers are ASMs like carbamazepine.

questions.stem: Which medication is most associated with reversible gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism?
questions.explanation: Phenytoin causes gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism. Others do not commonly cause this.

questions.stem: An antidote for benzodiazepine overdose (with seizure risk) is:
questions.explanation: Flumazenil reverses benzodiazepines but can precipitate withdrawal/ seizures. Naloxone is for opioids. Physostigmine reverses anticholinergics. Atropine is antimuscarinic.

questions.stem: Which Alzheimer’s disease medication is an NMDA receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation: Memantine is an NMDA antagonist. Donepezil/rivastigmine/galantamine are cholinesterase inhibitors.

questions.stem: Which drug used for neuropathic pain is a calcium channel alpha-2-delta ligand?
questions.explanation: Gabapentin (and pregabalin) bind α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels. Duloxetine/TCAs are SNRIs/TCAs; tramadol is μ-agonist/SNRI.

questions.stem: Which antiepileptic most commonly causes hyponatremia via SIADH?
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine (and oxcarbazepine) cause SIADH/hyponatremia. Others less so.

questions.stem: Mechanism of riluzole in ALS includes:
options: NMDA antagonism and decreased glutamate release
questions.explanation: Riluzole reduces glutamatergic excitotoxicity via NMDA antagonism and reduced glutamate release; also has Na+ channel effects.

questions.stem: Which MS therapy is integrin-blocking and carries PML risk?
questions.explanation: Natalizumab (α4-integrin blocker) increases risk of PML (JC virus).

questions.stem: Most appropriate preventive therapy for frequent menstrual migraine with aura when estrogen is contraindicated:
questions.explanation: Topiramate is effective and avoids estrogen-related stroke risk in aura. Propranolol is reasonable but less specific to catamenial patterns; CGRP mAbs are options but cost/coverage vary.

questions.stem: A patient on MAO-B inhibitor selegiline develops hyperthermia, agitation, and clonus after starting sertraline. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: MAO-B inhibitors plus SSRIs can precipitate serotonin syndrome: hyperthermia, clonus, agitation. NMS is dopamine blockade with rigidity and high CPK.

questions.stem: Which antipsychotic is preferred in Parkinson disease psychosis due to minimal D2 blockade?
questions.explanation: Quetiapine (and clozapine, pimavanserin) are preferred; haloperidol/risperidone worsen parkinsonism.

questions.stem: Which drug can cause acute angle-closure glaucoma and paresthesias by carbonic anhydrase inhibition?
questions.explanation: Topiramate inhibits carbonic anhydrase; zonisamide also weakly inhibits but topiramate is classic.

questions.stem: Which medication for essential tremor has the strongest evidence?
questions.explanation: Propranolol and primidone are first-line; levodopa and amantadine are for PD, not ET.

questions.stem: Which drug combination is most likely to precipitate hypertensive crisis with tyramine-rich foods?
questions.explanation: Nonselective MAOIs prevent tyramine metabolism → hypertensive crisis. Low-dose selegiline patch is MAO-B selective; SSRIs/bupropion do not cause tyramine crises.

questions.stem: Which AED binds synaptic vesicle protein SV2A?
questions.explanation: Levetiracetam binds SV2A; others have different mechanisms.

questions.stem: Key adverse effect requiring REMS for clozapine is:
questions.explanation: Clozapine requires CBC monitoring for agranulocytosis; myocarditis and seizures are notable risks.

questions.stem: Which drug is most effective for RLS but risks augmentation and impulse-control disorders?
questions.explanation: Dopamine agonists (pramipexole/ropinirole) work but can cause augmentation/ICD; gabapentinoids are alternatives.

questions.stem: Primary mechanism of botulinum toxin for cervical dystonia:
options: Blocks presynaptic acetylcholine release at NMJ
questions.explanation: Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins to inhibit ACh release.

questions.stem: Which triptan has the longest half-life and lowest recurrence risk?
questions.explanation: Frovatriptan has the longest half-life; useful for prolonged attacks or menstrual migraine prophylaxis.

questions.stem: Which medication is a first-line disease-modifying therapy for Alzheimer disease?
questions.explanation: Cholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil/rivastigmine/galantamine) are first-line for mild–moderate AD; memantine is added in moderate–severe.

questions.stem: Which drug reduces relapse in NMOSD with anti-AQP4 positivity by depleting B cells?
questions.explanation: Rituximab (anti-CD20) depletes B cells and is effective in NMOSD; interferons may worsen NMOSD.

questions.stem: Common cause of reversible posterior leukoencephalopathy syndrome (PRES) includes:
questions.explanation: PRES is linked to hypertension, eclampsia, and calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus).

questions.stem: Which agent is best for acute cluster headache?
questions.explanation: Cluster headaches respond to high-flow oxygen and SC triptan; oral agents act too slowly.

questions.stem: Which antiemetic carries high risk of QT prolongation and torsades, especially IV?
questions.explanation: Ondansetron prolongs QT, particularly IV/high dose. Others carry some risk but less pronounced.

questions.stem: Which MS oral therapy requires first-dose observation for bradycardia/AV block?
questions.explanation: Fingolimod (S1P modulator) can cause first-dose bradycardia; monitor EKG.

questions.stem: A patient with Parkinson disease on high-dose levodopa develops dyskinesias. Which adjustment best reduces dyskinesias while maintaining 'on' time?
questions.explanation: Amantadine (NMDA antagonist) reduces L-dopa–induced dyskinesias. Increasing L-dopa worsens them. Anticholinergics help tremor, not dyskinesias.

questions.stem: Postherpetic neuralgia inadequately controlled on gabapentin; best next step with least systemic AEs:
questions.explanation: Topical lidocaine is effective and well tolerated. Opioids/ketamine carry systemic risks; carbamazepine is more for trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.stem: Which AED can worsen myoclonic and absence seizures in generalized epilepsy?
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine may aggravate generalized myoclonic/absence seizures.

questions.stem: Lithium toxicity risk increases with which medication change?
questions.explanation: Thiazides reduce lithium clearance leading to toxicity. NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors also raise levels; low-dose aspirin has minimal effect.

questions.stem: Which combination most likely precipitates neuroleptic malignant syndrome?
questions.explanation: NMS is due to dopamine blockade (often high-potency antipsychotics or dose escalation): rigidity, hyperthermia, high CPK.

questions.stem: A 28-year-old with new generalized tonic–clonic seizures is started on valproate. Two months later she plans pregnancy. Best strategy?
options: Switch to levetiracetam or lamotrigine with folate
questions.explanation: Switch to safer ASM preconception if possible; levetiracetam/lamotrigine have better safety. Avoid abrupt cessation.

questions.stem: Which antipsychotic carries highest metabolic syndrome risk?
questions.explanation: Clozapine and olanzapine have the greatest metabolic risk; ziprasidone/aripiprazole less so.

questions.stem: Which drug blocks CGRP receptor for migraine prevention?
questions.explanation: Erenumab is a CGRP receptor mAb. Others are different classes for prevention.

questions.stem: Status epilepticus persisting after lorazepam and levetiracetam: best next step per guidelines?
questions.explanation: Second-line includes fosphenytoin/phenytoin, valproate, or levetiracetam; refractory cases need anesthetic coma.

questions.stem: A 65-year-old with Alzheimer disease on donepezil develops bradycardia and syncope. Best action?
questions.explanation: Cholinesterase inhibitors can cause bradycardia; stopping avoids recurrent syncope. Patch still has cholinergic effects.

questions.stem: For acute ischemic stroke within 4.5 hours with disabling deficit and no contraindications, which drug is indicated?
questions.explanation: IV thrombolysis (alteplase; tenecteplase in many centers) is indicated; anticoagulation/GP IIb/IIIa are not first-line.

questions.stem: Which MS agent requires varicella immunity screening and can cause macular edema?
questions.explanation: Fingolimod (S1P modulator) requires VZV immunity and can cause macular edema and bradycardia.

questions.stem: Medication overuse headache is MOST associated with frequent use of:
questions.explanation: MOH is common with butalbital/opioids and frequent triptan/NSAID use.

questions.stem: Which dementia therapy can worsen Lewy body dementia hallucinations least?
questions.explanation: Quetiapine (or clozapine) is preferred; others worsen parkinsonism/hallucinations.

questions.stem: Which opioid has SNRI properties and higher seizure risk?
questions.explanation: Tramadol lowers seizure threshold and is serotonergic; others lack this SNRI feature.

questions.stem: A patient on linezolid develops agitation, hyperreflexia, and diaphoresis after triptan use. Etiology?
questions.explanation: Linezolid is an MAOI → serotonin excess with serotonergic agents like triptans/SSRIs.

questions.stem: Mechanism of lamotrigine relevant to mood stabilization:
options: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels and glutamate release
questions.explanation: Lamotrigine blocks Na+ channels and reduces glutamate release; useful in bipolar depression and epilepsy.

questions.stem: Most appropriate abortive therapy for hemiplegic migraine:
questions.explanation: Avoid vasoconstrictors (triptans/ergots) in hemiplegic migraine; use NSAIDs/antiemetics.

questions.stem: Which antiemetic is a D2 antagonist that can worsen parkinsonism?
questions.explanation: Metoclopramide blocks D2 and can cause/worsen parkinsonism and tardive dyskinesia.

questions.stem: Management of neuroleptic malignant syndrome includes:
options: Continue antipsychotic and add benzodiazepine only
Immediate cessation of antipsychotic, supportive care, dantrolene or bromocriptine
questions.explanation: Stop offending agent; supportive ICU care; dantrolene or dopamine agonists are used.

questions.stem: Which AED requires HLA-B*1502 screening in many Asian populations due to SJS/TEN risk?
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine is associated with SJS/TEN in HLA-B*1502 carriers; screening recommended in at-risk populations.

questions.stem: Which drug reduces spasticity via alpha-2 agonism at the spinal cord?
questions.explanation: Tizanidine is an alpha-2 agonist; baclofen is GABA-B agonist; diazepam is GABA-A PAM; dantrolene acts on ryanodine receptors in muscle.

questions.stem: Which antiepileptic is enzyme-inducing and lowers efficacy of oral contraceptives the MOST?
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine induces CYP enzymes reducing OCP effectiveness; valproate inhibits enzymes; levetiracetam and lamotrigine have less effect.

questions.stem: Which medication best prevents post-SAH delayed cerebral ischemia?
questions.explanation: Nimodipine, a DHP CCB, improves outcomes post-SAH by reducing risk of delayed ischemia/vasospasm.

questions.stem: Most appropriate prophylaxis for episodic migraine in an obese patient concerned about weight gain:
questions.explanation: Topiramate can promote weight loss; valproate/amitriptyline cause weight gain; propranolol is weight-neutral but may worsen fatigue.

questions.stem: Which MS agent causes infusion reactions and reactivation of hepatitis B?
questions.explanation: Anti-CD20 therapy (ocrelizumab) risks HBV reactivation; screen prior to initiation.

questions.stem: Mechanism of tiagabine:
questions.explanation: Tiagabine blocks GABA reuptake via GAT-1, increasing synaptic GABA.

questions.stem: For trigeminal neuralgia, the first-line pharmacotherapy is:
questions.explanation: Carbamazepine (or oxcarbazepine) is first-line for trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.stem: Which drug combination increases risk of serotonin syndrome the MOST?
questions.explanation: MAOI plus SSRI markedly raises serotonin; triptan + SSRI risk is lower; SNRI + bupropion less serotonergic.

questions.stem: Which PD medication directly stimulates D2/D3 receptors and is associated with ICDs?
questions.explanation: Dopamine agonists (ropinirole/pramipexole) cause ICDs (gambling, hypersexuality). Carbidopa is a decarboxylase inhibitor.

questions.stem: Which AED has the highest risk of hepatic failure and aplastic anemia (REMS)?
questions.explanation: Felbamate carries rare but severe hepatic failure and aplastic anemia risks.

questions.stem: Which cholinesterase inhibitor is available as a transdermal patch?
questions.explanation: Rivastigmine has an available patch formulation; others are oral.

questions.stem: Mechanism of perampanel:
questions.explanation: Perampanel is a noncompetitive AMPA antagonist.

questions.stem: Which agent treats MS spasticity refractory to oral meds via intrathecal delivery?
questions.explanation: Intrathecal baclofen pumps are used for severe spasticity unresponsive to oral therapy.

questions.stem: Drug most associated with benign intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri)?
questions.explanation: Tetracyclines (minocycline) and vitamin A derivatives are linked to IIH.

questions.stem: Which ASM can cause visual field constriction requiring periodic ophthalmologic exams?
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin can cause irreversible peripheral visual field loss.

questions.stem: Which antipsychotic has the lowest EPS risk and partial agonism at D2?
questions.explanation: Aripiprazole is a D2 partial agonist with low EPS; haloperidol/risperidone are higher EPS risk.

questions.stem: Most appropriate acute therapy for severe agitation in delirium tremens with autonomic instability:
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines are first-line for DTs; antipsychotics may be adjunctive.

questions.stem: Which migraine preventive is contraindicated in uncontrolled hypertension and CAD due to vasoconstriction?
questions.explanation: Ergots are vasoconstrictors and contraindicated in vascular disease; propranolol is often used for HTN.

questions.stem: Which drug is an NMDA antagonist used in anesthesia with risk of emergence reactions?
questions.explanation: Ketamine is an NMDA antagonist causing dissociative anesthesia and emergence phenomena.

questions.stem: Topiramate common cognitive adverse effect is: (case 71)
questions.explanation: Topiramate can cause cognitive slowing and anomia. Parkinsonism is from D2 blockade; euphoria is uncommon; depression less typical.

questions.stem: Which medication for neuropathic pain is a dual SNRI with evidence in diabetic neuropathy? (case 72)
questions.explanation: Duloxetine is an SNRI with strong evidence for diabetic neuropathy; gabapentin/TCAs also effective but different class.

questions.stem: Which drug for MS induces lymphopenia via S1P receptor modulation causing sequestration of lymphocytes? (case 73)
questions.explanation: Fingolimod traps lymphocytes in lymph nodes via S1P modulation.

questions.stem: In myasthenia gravis crisis refractory to pyridostigmine, best immunomodulatory acute therapy? (case 74)
questions.explanation: IVIG or PLEX are effective acute therapies for MG exacerbations; baclofen and muscle relaxants are not indicated.

questions.stem: Which opioid antagonist has the longest duration, useful in opioid use disorder maintenance? (case 75)
questions.explanation: Naltrexone is long-acting; naloxone is short-acting rescue; buprenorphine is a partial agonist.
